[[File:Taco Truck St Louis MO.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|A [[taco truck]] in the downtown area of St. Louis, Missouri]] The phrase "'''taco trucks on every corner'''" was used by [[Marco Gutierrez]], the co-founder of ''Latinos for Trump,'' on September 1, 2016, in comments that received widespread attention during the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 United States presidential elections]].
During an interview with MSNBC, Gutierrez referred to his Mexican heritage, stating that "My culture is a very dominant culture, and it's imposing and it's causing problems. If you don't do something about it, you're going to have taco trucks on every corner." His remarks subsequently met with both sarcasm and criticism, many mocking the statement on social media and sending #TacosOnEveryCorner to the top of Twitter's list of trending topics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/03/us/politics/taco-trucks-on-every-corner-trump-supporters-anti-immigration-warning.html|title='Taco Trucks on Every Corner': Trump Supporter's Anti-Immigration Warning|last=Chokshi|first=Niraj|date=2016-09-02|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-10-26}}</ref> Others expressed concern over his remarks, stating that he was using "coded language that politicians and pundits use to get away with explicitly racist messages — from crime to immigration and terrorism." Taco trucks were used as voter registration-information booths in Houston Texas, and a nationwide ''Guac the Vote'' campaign was launched.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/9/2/12768774/trump-taco-trucks|title=Trump surrogate warns of scary future with "taco trucks" on "every corner"|last=Lopez|first=German|date=2016-09-02|website=Vox|access-date=2016-10-26}}</ref> [[NPR|National Public Radio]] (NPR) news wrote that [[taco]] [[Food truck|trucks]] "now straddle the worlds of [[Political symbolism|political symbol]] and [[internet meme]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/09/03/492534979/taco-truck-owner-racks-up-sales-at-trump-event-in-detroit|title=Taco Truck Owner Racks Up Sales At Trump Event In Detroit|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[NPR]]|access-date=2016-09-03|quote=Donald Trump's visit to an African American church in Detroit brought both cheers and protests Saturday — but one of the star attractions was a taco truck. One of the humble vehicles, which now straddle the worlds of political symbol and internet meme, was parked outside.}}</ref>
== Origin == The phrase originated with Marco Gutierrez, a co-founder of the group ''Latinos for Trump'', during an interview with [[Joy-Ann Reid|Joy Reid]] on [[MSNBC]] on September 1, 2016.
The phrase was used within the context of a warning about the "dominance" of [[Culture of Mexico|Mexican culture]], underscoring Gutierrez's stance that immigration should be more closely regulated.{{efn|"While on All in With Chris Hayes on Thursday evening, Latinos for Trump founder Marco Gutierrez warned of the danger of allowing Mexican culture to enter the United States unabated."<ref>{{cite web|author=Rodriguez, Mathew | date= September 2, 2016 | url=https://mic.com/articles/153367/latino-donald-trump-supporter-says-more-mexicans-means-a-taco-truck-on-every-corner#.2DujMnmZJ|title=Latino Donald Trump supporter says more Mexicans means a taco truck on every corner|publisher=[[Mic.com]]|accessdate=10 September 2016}}</ref>}}
In an interview with [[Deutsche Welle]] on September 8, 2016, Gutierrez explained, "If you don't regulate the immigration, if you don't structure our communities, we are going to do whatever we want. We are going to take over. That is what I'm trying to say and I think what is happening with my culture is that its imposing [itself] on the American culture – and both cultures are reacting."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/trump-supporters-taco-trucks-remark-sparks-online-anger-and-hunger/a-19536870|title=Trump supporter's 'taco trucks' remark sparks online anger – and hunger|last=Machhaus|first=Carolina|date=2016-09-08|website=[[Deutsche Welle]]|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Reactions == * Online responses followed immediately after the interview.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/09/03/us/ap-us-taco-trucks-reaction.html|title=Trump Supporter's 'Taco Trucks' Remark Draws Mockery|last=|first=|date=2016-09-03|work=|newspaper=[[The Associated Press]] via [[The New York Times]]|issn=0362-4331|quote=The social media onslaught was in reaction to a Thursday night interview on MSNBC with Latinos for Trump founder Marco Gutierrez, who said the Mexican culture is "dominant" and "imposing" before issuing his taco warning.|access-date=2016-09-03|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/09/02/492390405/-memeoftheweek-taco-trucks-on-every-corner|title=#MemeOfTheWeek: Taco Trucks On Every Corner|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[NPR]]|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rt.com/usa/358094-trump-taco-truck-corner/|title=Threat of 'taco truck on every corner' backfires as internet cheers|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[RT (TV network)]]|language=en-EN|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.univision.com/estilo-de-vida/trending/por-que-todo-el-mundo-esta-hablando-de-los-taco-trucks-on-every-corner|title=¿Por qué todo el mundo está hablando de los 'taco trucks on every corner'?|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Univision]]|language=[[Spanish language]]|trans-title=Why everyone is talking about the 'taco trucks on every corner'?|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/fishbowldc/taco-trucks-on-every-corner-the-warning-that-wasnt/158961|title='Taco Trucks on Every Corner': The Warning That Wasn't|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Adweek]]|access-date=|quote=Bad, bad choice of analogy on Gutierrez's part. His larger point, whatever that may have been, was immediately swallowed up at the mention of tacos. Who doesn't love tacos?}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] described the online response as a "social media onslaught".<ref name=":4" /> On September 3, 2016, ''#TacoTrucksOnEveryCorner'' was the top hashtag on [[Twitter]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/2016/0903/TacoTrucksOnEveryCorner-Why-that-threat-backfired|title=#TacoTrucksOnEveryCorner: Why that threat backfired|last=|first=|date=2016-09-03|work=|newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|issn=0882-7729|quote=Not only did many critics immediately dismiss Gutierrez' remarks as racist, but several also remarked upon the love that many Americans have for Mexican food. By midnight, the #TacoTrucksOnEveryCorner was the No. 1 hashtag on Twitter.|access-date=|via=}}</ref> * A taco truck voter registration drive in Houston drove a dramatic increase in the city's voter registration. Houston Chronicle<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Taco-trucks-are-the-new-frontier-of-voter-9394645.php|title=Taco trucks are the new frontier of voter registration drives|work=Houston Chronicle|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref> reported that the effort "...is a trend that prompted Harris County Clerk Stan Stanart to call a news conference Wednesday, just a few blocks from the Tacos Tierra Caliente truck, to encourage people to vote early and avoid the crowds." Houston Chronicle<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/politics/houston/articleComments/Volunteers-register-record-number-of-voters-in-9965381.php|title=Volunteers register record number of voters in Harris County|work=Houston Chronicle|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref> later reported that "As registration closed, Harris County's voter roster had grown by more than 6 percent since 2014, the steepest increase in 16 years. More than 323,890 new names have been added." <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/news/2016/09/28/171552/harris-county-pushes-early-voting-in-expectation-of-high-presidential-election-turnout/|title=Harris County Pushes Early Voting, In Expectation of High Presidential Election Turnout {{!}} Houston Public Media|last=Schneider|first=Andrew|date=2016-09-28|access-date=2016-09-30}}</ref> The initiative was widely covered in local, national, and international news media.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/tacos-side-civics-trucks-texas-register-voters/story?id=42433746|title=Taco Truck Voter Registration Campaign Launches in Texas|last=|first=|date=2016-09-29|website=ABC News|access-date=2016-09-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-tacos-idUSKCN11Z2YP|title=Houston taco trucks register voters as Latinos flex political muscle|date=2016-09-30|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=2016-09-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Taco-trucks-are-the-new-frontier-of-voter-9394645.php|title=Taco trucks are the new frontier of voter registration drives|access-date=2016-09-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/09/30/us/politics/ap-us-texas-taco-truck-voter-registration.html|title='Guac the Vote:' Houston Taco Trucks Seek to Register Voters|last=The Associated Press|date=2016-09-30|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=2016-09-30|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> * The [[United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce]] started a ''Guac the Vote'' campaign to use taco trucks to register voters and to appear at polling stations on election day. The campaign name is a reference to [[guacamole]].{{efn|"On Tuesday, the Hispanic Chamber, which says it represents 4.1 million Hispanic-owned businesses nationwide, took things a step further, announcing a "Guac the Vote" campaign to encourage taco truck owners to register customers to vote and then to park outside polling sites on Election Day in a symbolic, if tasty, protest of Gutierrez's comments."<ref name="WP-1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/09/06/taco-trucks-on-every-corner-business-group-wants-them-at-every-polling-site-instead/|title=Taco trucks on every corner? Business group wants them at every polling site instead.|last=|first=|date=2016-09-06|website=[[Washington Post]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-06}}</ref>}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/latino-business-group-starts-guac-vote-effort-n643551|title=Latino business group starts 'Guac The Vote' effort|last=|first=|date=2016-09-06|website=|publisher=[[NBC News]]|access-date=2016-09-07|quote=The U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce is trying to turn the "taco trucks on every corner" comment made by a Donald Trump supporter into a voter registration campaign dubbed Guac The Vote.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rt.com/usa/358716-taco-truck-voter-registration/|title=#GuacTheVote: Latino business group wants taco trucks to register voters|last=|first=|date=2016-09-08|website=|publisher=[[Russia Today]]|language=en-EN|access-date=2016-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.twcnews.com/tx/austin/news/2016/09/8/-guac-the-vote--takes-aim-at-hungry-unregistered-voters--.html|title='Guac the Vote' Takes Aim at Hungry Unregistered Voters|last=|first=|date=2016-09-08|website=|publisher=[[Time Warner Cable News]]|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://munchies.vice.com/en/articles/latinos-are-co-opting-the-taco-trucks-on-every-corner-threat-to-guac-the-vote|title=Latinos Are Co-Opting the 'Taco Trucks on Every Corner' Threat to 'Guac the Vote'|last=|first=|date=2016-09-09|website=[[Vice.com]]|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailymeal.com/news/eat/guac-vote-will-register-voters-taco-trucks-every-corner/091216|title='Guac the Vote' Will Register Voters at Taco Trucks on Every Corner|last=|first=|date=|website=[[The Daily Meal]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-12|quote=Latinos for Trump made headlines this month when one if its members warned voters of an "ominous future" with "taco trucks on every corner." === In popular culture === * Sales of the song ''I Love You More Than Tacos'' by the [[Latin music (genre)|latin music]] band [[Carne Cruda]] increased. The song is about "a man's love so profound that he would give his tacos and burritos to someone else".<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.univision.com/univision-news/culture/heres-an-anthem-for-taco-lovers-and-tacotruckoneverycorner-supporters|title=Here's an anthem for taco lovers and #TacoTruckOnEveryCorner supporters|last=|first=|date=2016-09-07|website=[[Univision]]|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> [[Univision]] reported that the song "has become something of an anthem in the wake of the #TacoTruckOnEveryCorner controversy."<ref name=":3" /> * On October 21, 2016 American singer and [[musical theatre]] actress [[Leslie Kritzer]] released a satirical song titled ''Taco Truck Invasion''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/leslie-kritzer-is-riff-tina-in-new-video-taco-truck-invasion|title=Leslie Kritzer Is Riff-Tina in New Video, "Taco Truck Invasion"|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Playbill]]|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> [[Entertainment Weekly]] wrote that "Kritzer battles the derogatory statement made by Gutierrez, who also founded Latinos for Trump, with humor by embodying her alter-ego Riff-Tina, dancing through the streets with a taco truck by her side."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/10/19/taco-truck-invasion-parody-video-trump-anti-immigration-stance|title='Taco Truck Invasion' Satire Combats Trump's Anti-Immigration Stance|last=|first=|date=|work=|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
== Polling == In a survey of 1,898 American adults conducted on September 3, 2016, market research firm [[YouGov]] reported that 58% would be happy "if there was a taco truck on your corner".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://today.yougov.com/opi/surveys/results#/survey/2483f3c0-7118-11e6-8c3c-005056a81451|title=Taco Trucks results|last=|first=|date=2016-09-03|website=|publisher=[[YouGov]]|access-date=2016-09-09|quote=2. Would you be happy or unhappy if there was a taco truck on your corner? Happy 58%, Unhappy 16%, Not sure 26%}}</ref>
In an [[opinion poll]] of 744 [[likely voters]] conducted in [[Florida]] from September 4 to 6, 2016, polling firm [[Public Policy Polling]] reported that "tacos and taco trucks are pretty popular among voters who have opinions on them."<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/main/2016/09/presidential-race-up-for-grabs-in-florida.html|title=Presidential Race Up for Grabs in Florida|last=|first=|date=2016-09-07|website=|publisher=[[Public Policy Polling]]|access-date=2016-09-08|quote=In the wake of last week's controversy we find that tacos and taco trucks are pretty popular among voters who have opinions on them. Tacos have a +36 net favorability with 47% of voters seeing them positively to 11% with a negative view. And taco trucks have a +30 net favorability with 42% of voters seeing them positively to 12% with a negative view. There's a pretty significant party divide on the 'issue' of taco trucks though- they're at +43 with Democrats (51/8) but only +7 with Republicans (23/16)}}</ref><ref>http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/2015/PPP_Release_FL_90716.pdf</ref> The firm reported tacos had a +36% net favorability, and taco trucks had a +30% net favorability, with a "pretty significant party divide on the 'issue' of taco trucks".<ref name=":2" />

'''Working Women United''' (also known as the '''Working Women United Institute''') is a [[women's rights]] organisation based in the United States which was formed in New York City, in 1975, to combat sexual harassment of women in the workplace.
According to some researchers, the organization was the first to use the term "[[sexual harassment]]" in the workplace context.<ref name=fitz>Fitzgerald, Louise F. "Sexual harassment: The definition and measurement of a construct." Ivory power: Sexual harassment on campus 21, no. 22 (1990): 24-30.</ref> In the beginning of the organization's activism, their definition for sexual harassment was "the treatment of women workers as sexual objects," but the organization did not specify which behaviors constituted such harassment.<ref>Loy, Pamela Hewitt, and Lea P. Stewart. "The extent and effects of the sexual harassment of working women." Sociological focus 17, no. 1 (1984): 31-43.</ref>
==Carmita Wood== The founding of the group was inspired by the case of '''Carmita Wood''', who quit her job at Cornell University due to sexual harassment and became one of the first women in the US to sue her employer on such grounds.<ref name=fitz/>
In 1975, Carmita Wood quit her position at Cornell University due to harassment from her supervisor, [[Boyce McDaniel]], and the University refused to approve of a transfer. Subsequently, Wood filed for unemployment benefits from the university. Cornell refused to approve the benefits, stating Wood had quit for "personal reasons." Working Women United was active in response to the incident and Wood's subsequent lawsuit. Cornell instructor [[Lin Farley]], a key organiser in Working Women United, used the phrase "sexual harassment" at a hearing of the [[New York City Human Rights Commission]], and ''The New York Times'' reported on the hearing and the phrase used, helping to introduce the concept and phrase "sexual harassment" into the national lexicon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theweek.com/articles/738873/depressingly-long-history-sexual-harassment-turning-points|website=The Week|title=The depressingly long history of sexual harassment}}</ref>
